summary: Brockway McMillan was a member of the President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board (PFIAB) during the period covered by these documents (1963-1964). The documents consist of meeting minutes and agendas of the PFIAB, indicating McMillan's participation in discussions and briefings related to various intelligence activities and national security matters. These included topics such as intelligence coverage of Cuba, covert operations, the National Reconnaissance Program, signals intelligence (SIGINT), and the Soviet Bloc threat. McMillan's presence at these meetings suggests he was involved in advising the President on foreign intelligence matters, although the specific nature of his contributions is not detailed in these summaries.
significance: Based on the provided documents, Brockway McMillan's significance in the JFK context is related to his role as a member of the President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board (PFIAB). The PFIAB advised President Kennedy (and later President Johnson) on intelligence matters, including those related to Cuba and the Soviet Union. While the documents do not explicitly link McMillan to the JFK assassination, his involvement in the PFIAB places him within a network of individuals advising the President on national security issues during that period.
